displayed_text:
[Question]

What is your opinion on internet influencers (e.g., streamers, bloggers, short video creators) increasingly becoming a recognized profession?

answer.text_box: I think it’s a disgrace. Especially cause of the fact that they make a lot more money than people who actually contribute positively in society, it’s a complete joke what this world has turned into.

displayed_text:
Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Summary of viewpoints

  • Overall sentiment: Roughly 50–60% express positive or conditionally positive views (seeing influencing as a valid profession and evolution of media), about 25–35% are skeptical or negative (citing fakeness, saturation, and social harm), and the remainder are mixed or neutral (“not for me, but fine for others”).

  • Perceived benefits:

  • Democratizes opportunity and entrepreneurship; enables people to earn from anywhere.
  • Offers entertainment, education, product discovery, and niche community building.
  • Shifts advertising and commerce toward relatable, peer-style recommendations.
  • Supplements or, for some, replaces traditional media; increased diversity of voices.

  • Competition can improve content quality and accuracy.

  • Major concerns:

  • Authenticity and ethics: perceived fakeness, grifting, and pay-to-pitch dynamics.
  • Misinformation and echo chambers, especially when influencers become sole news sources.
  • Oversaturation and a “race to extremes” for attention; pressure to be outrageous.
  • Impact on youth: glamorizing “easy money,” crowding out studies/trades, parasocial fixation.
  • Consumerism and overconsumption; disproportionate earnings vs. traditional professions.
  • Platform risks: algorithm volatility, precarious income, mental health strain.

  • Cultural fragmentation (“everyone builds their own brand”), eroding shared understanding.

  • Conditions and recommendations for legitimacy:

  • Accountability and professional standards comparable to other fields.
  • Transparency about sponsorships, ads, and AI use; clear labeling and disclosures.
  • Media literacy for audiences (especially younger viewers); don’t rely on influencers as the sole news source.
  • Ethical guidelines, platform safeguards, and possibly unionization or fair-contract protections.

  • Emphasize that success requires real work; encourage alternative education/career paths alongside content creation.

  • Observed trends:

  • Rapid growth during the pandemic; normalization as a career path in recent years.
  • Influencers seen as today’s celebrities—more accessible but also more exposed.
  • Social video is displacing traditional TV for many, with both positive and problematic effects.

Bottom line: Many accept influencing as a legitimate profession—akin to entertainment and small-business ownership—when it’s authentic, transparent, and socially responsible. Support is tempered by concerns about misinformation, commercialization, youth impact, and market saturation, prompting calls for clearer standards, education, and safeguards.

Summary B

The comments reflect a wide range of perspectives on internet influencers and their status as a recognized profession. A significant portion of the feedback is positive, with many acknowledging the opportunities influencers provide for entertainment, information, and connection. Commenters often highlight the accessibility of the profession, the ability to earn a living through creativity, and the role influencers play in shaping trends and offering relatable content. Some compare influencers to traditional media figures, noting their growing influence and the shift in how people consume content and make purchasing decisions.

However, there are also critical perspectives. Some commenters express concerns about the authenticity and responsibility of influencers, noting that the field can be saturated and that many may come across as inauthentic or overly self-promotional. A few raise ethical concerns, such as the potential for misleading audiences about success or the need for greater accountability in an industry that lacks formal regulation.

There is also a recurring theme of concern about the broader cultural impact of influencers, with some suggesting that the phenomenon reflects a societal shift toward individualism and a loss of shared understanding. Others point to the pressures of maintaining relevance and the tendency for content to become repetitive or overly trend-driven.

Overall, the comments suggest that while the role of internet influencers is widely recognized and valued by many, there is also a call for greater authenticity, responsibility, and critical awareness of the profession’s broader implications.
